character.definition:
Summary of the PhD project:
Dickeya dadantii is a Gram-negative phytopathogenic bacterium responsible for soft rot disease in a 
wide range of plant species including economically important crops. Symptoms are mostly the 
result of plant cell wall degradation by pectinases and proteases produced by bacteria. During the 
infection process, the bacterium is confronted with various challenges which require the correct 
spatio-temporal production of the different adaptive and virulence factors. Recently, competition in 
planta and phenotypic assays highlighted the importance of the protein Hfq in the regulation of D. 
dadantii virulence. The regulatory role of this protein is ascribed mainly to its RNA chaperone 
function facilitating interactions between bacterial non-coding RNA and its mRNA targets. 
However, Hfq is one of the most abundant protein in the cell also described as a Nucleoid- 
Associated Protein involved in the organization of the nucleoid and the control of gene expression. 
Both functions have been studied separately so far in bacteria. The aim of this project is to identify 
which part of Hfq regulation is associated with its RNA chaperone activity and which one with its 
nucleoid associated protein activity and finally to decipher mechanisms by which Hfq controls D. 
dadantii virulence.
Scientific Background:
Dickeya dadantii is a Gram-negative phytopathogenic bacterium responsible for soft rot disease in a 
wide range of plant species including economically important crops (e.g. potato, chicory, sugar 
beet) and many ornamental plants (Ma et al., 2007). It causes important production losses. 
Virulence mechanisms  of  D. dadantii  have been extensively studied. The infection process  is 
divided in two distinct phases: (i) an asymptomatic phase when the bacterium penetrates into the 
host  and   progresses   through   intercellular   spaces   without  multiplying   substantially;   (ii)   a 
symptomatic  phase  associated  with  a  strong  increase  in  bacterial  fitness  and  multiplication. 
Acclimatation to these disease stages requires a tight regulation of the production of the different 
adaptive and virulence factors (Reverchon and Nasser, 2013).
To characterize the regulation of this pathogenic process, investigations on D. dadantii have mostly 
focused on its control by DNA-binding transcription factors (Reverchon and Nasser, 2013; Leonard 
et al., 2017). Additional studies about the regulatory role of chromosome dynamics involving 
Nucleoid-Associated proteins and post-transcriptional regulation by regulatory RNAs (sRNAs) 
have been also performed (Ouafa et al., 2012; Jiang et al., 2015; Meyer et al., 2018)(Leonard et al., 
2019).
Nucleoid-Associated Proteins (NAPs) are abundant proteins which contribute to both the 
organization of the nucleoid and the control of gene expression. Among them H-NS, Fis and IHF 
have been involved in the regulation of the virulence in D. dadantii (Reverchon et al., 2021). Post- 
transcriptional regulation is defined as the control of gene expression at the RNA  level and 
classically occurs through base-pairing interactions between regulatory RNAs (sRNAs) and 
mRNAs.
